nachos.machine

Class SerialPort

  • java.lang.Object
    • nachos.machine.SerialPort

  • public class SerialPort
extends java.lang.Object
    This class simulates a simplified version of a UART (Universal Asynchronous Receiver/Transmitter) device. A UART (such as the National Semiconductor 16X50 series) is used to perform serial communication between computers and other devices. The term "asynchronous" in the name refers to the fact that the devices communicating do not share a common clock. A typical application is the implementation of serial communication ("com") ports on a PC. In such an application, there is one UART at the sender and another at the receiver. The UART at the sender handles the task of taking a byte to be transmitted and outputting it in bit-serial fashion on the transmission line. The UART at the receiver is responsible for detecting the arrival of data, converting the serially arriving bits into bytes, and detecting errors. These functions are handled automatically by the UART. The sender is simply responsible for presenting bytes to be transmitted at appropriate times. The receiver is responsible for noticing when complete bytes of data have been received and storing them in memory. The receiver is also responsible for responding to error conditions detected by the UART. Both the sender and receiver cooperate in implementing a flow-control scheme. Flow control can be performed in "software" mode, without the direct support of the UART, or in "hardware" mode, which uses special "out-of-band" signals supported by the UART.

    A UART is operated by reading and writing control bits to/from control and status registers, and reading and writing data to/from data registers. The registers provided in the current simulation are as follows:

    Data registers:

    TDR
    transmitter data register: data bytes to be transmitted are written to this register.
    RDR
    receiver data register: received data bytes are read from this register.

    Line status register (LSR): contains the following status bits:

    RRDY
    receiver ready: there is received data to be read from the RDR.
    TRDY
    transmitter ready: the UART is prepared to accept data for transmission in the TDR.
    RERR
    receiver error: serial data arriving at the UART did not conform to the format required by the line protocol.
    ROR
    receiver overrun: new data has arrived before the previously received data was removed from the RDR.

    Modem status register (MSR):

    CTS
    clear to send: hardware flow-control signal that indicates that the UART at the other end of the transmission line is prepared to receive data (wired to RTS on the UART at the other end of the transmission line).
    DSR
    data set ready: indicates that the UART at the remote end of the link is powered up and is ready to engage in communication (typically wired to DTR on the local UART).

    Modem control register (MCR):

    RTS
    request to send: hardware flow-control signal used to indicate the readiness of this UART to receive data (wired to CTS on the UART at the other end of the transmission line).
    DTR
    data terminal ready: indicates that the UART at the local end of the link is powered up and is ready to engage in communication (typically wired to DSR on the UART at the remote end of the link).

    • Method Detail

      • getLocalAddress

        public java.net.SocketAddress getLocalAddress()
        Get the address of the wire attached to this SerialPort, so that a remote port can connect to it.
        Returns:
        the address of the wire attached to this SerialPort.

      • connectTo

        public void connectTo(java.net.SocketAddress addr)
        Connect to the wire at a specified address, so that wire events emitted by this serial port will be transmitted over that wire to a remote port.
        Parameters:
        addr - The address of the wire, or null if loopback mode is to be used.

      • setHandler

        public void setHandler(InterruptHandler hand)
        Set the interrupt handler for this device.
        Parameters:
        hand - The interrupt handler to be called in case of an interrupt from this serial port.

      • getUnit

        public static SerialPort getUnit(int i)
        Get the SerialPort device with a specified unit number. The device is initialized if it has not yet been used.
        Parameters:
        i - The unit number of the device to get.
        Returns:
        the SerialPort device having the specified unit number.

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Shut down this SerialPort device.

      • readLSR

        public int readLSR()
        Read the line status register (LSR) and return the contents.
        Returns:
        the contents of the LSR.

      • readMSR

        public int readMSR()
        Read the modem status register (MSR) and return the contents.
        Returns:
        the contents of the MSR.

      • readMCR

        public int readMCR()
        Read the modem control register (MCR) and return the contents. The ability to read back the contents of the MCR (which is a control-only register) is a convenience that avoids the need for the driver to maintain a saved copy of the current state of the MCR bits.
        Returns:
        the contents of the MCR.

      • writeMCR

        public void writeMCR(int bits)
        Write the modem control register (MCR). This causes signals to propagate over the wire to the remote port.
        Parameters:
        bits - The data to be written into the MCR.

      • readRDR

        public byte readRDR()
        Read the receiver data register (RDR). LSR_RRDY is cleared as a side effect.
        Returns:
        the contents of the RDR, which is the last byte that was received.

      • writeTDR

        public void writeTDR(byte data)
        Write the transmitter data register (TDR). LSR_TRDY is cleared as a side effect and transmission begins.
        Parameters:
        data - The data byte to be transmitted.

      • showState

        public void showState()
        Print out the current SerialPort state.
